subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the
leading edge
of knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome, I’m Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today I’d like to
discuss the distinction between
the Super Ego and the Super Conscious
Mind. Now, I should begin by
saying that people sometimes tend to
think of these things
as things. But they are not really things.
They are concepts
designed to delineate processes that
take place within
consciousness. They are really not
identifiable with any particular organs
of the brain, for example. Although I
think at one time
the originators of these concepts maybe
hoped that that would be the case.
The Super Ego
is a concept that was developed by Freud.
Really, the Freudian dynamics of the
unconscious mind worked
very simply. They are like this. You have a
Super Ego which is sort of
the internalized parent, the critic, the
judge, saying: “You should do this,” “you should do
that,” “ you should be a good person,”
“you should be a good boy or a good girl.”
Then you have the Ego. You learn how to tie
your own shoelaces for example, get
dressed in the morning, make your bed, be
responsible for yourself.
Then you have the Id. That which sort
of lies
below consciousness, largely. It’s your
drives, your desires.
The unconscious part of that are the
parts that the Super
Ego thinks you ought not to possess,
like lust, anger,
a death wish even for people.
So, we go about our business
basically pushing certain things
out of consciousness because they
conflict
with the demands of the Super Ego. There
you have the
Freudian subconscious. Then
they come back,
you see, in slips of the tongue, in
humor, in dreams.
One might say that really in the 20th,
21st centuries
a big project of Western humanity is to
take the Freudian unconscious and make it
conscious. We see that in literature. We see
that in
film. We see that in all of the
portrayals of people expressing
themselves
publicly and doing things that in
previous generations
were not socially sanctioned.
It’s an important part of an
awakening process. Freudian psychology
is very, very powerful. At one time
it was considered, I think, the most significant
cultural force within psychology itself.
Now, the idea of the Super Conscious Mind
goes beyond the Super Ego.
The Super Conscious Mind, we don’t
know the outer boundaries of it. You
could equate the Super Conscious Mind
with creativity,
with inventors like Tesla who were
able to come up fully formed
with things like alternating current motors.
The various inventions of Tesla seemed
to just pop right out of his Super Conscious
Mind. The works of Shakespeare...
Of course, one might say the
great saints and mystics
of every culture express the Super
Conscious Mind,
the idea of Cosmic Consciousness, of
being aware
simultaneously of everything at once.
Now what does that mean in terms of
Freudian
consciousness? What does it mean to be
aware of everything
at once? First of all,
most people would say, “It would just blow my
circuits out, my nervous system
is not capable of handling
everything at once, I can’t even handle
the things that are in front of me right
now.” In fact, Freud would
even go so far as to say, “I can’t even
know myself
fully,” which is quite true.
But to know everything at once
means to be able to see
the darkness within oneself. That's where
it starts, actually. In the dark places,
in the hidden places, in the things
that we hide from ourselves.
I’ll tell you about
me. I’m going to share something I don’t
share very often.
When I was a child I liked to steal things.
I can remember as a four year old
child walking around the neighborhood,
where we
lived at the time in Levittown, New York,
where all the houses looked alike.
I’m wandering around
the neighborhood and other kids have
left their toys out in the
yards. So, I was picking up the toys
of all the other kids and bringing them
home. When I got home with those toys,
my parents saw what I had done and they
said, “You better return them,
they don’t belong to you.” Of course, I
didn’t even remember where I got them
but I walked around the neighborhood
distributing the toys at different
locations.
When I was ten years old I stole
books from a local bookstore. I even got
caught
by the bookstore owner. I was mortified.
He treated me gently. He said he wouldn’t
tell my parents
if I just returned the books, which I did.
But I have been aware since then
that I have a propensity to be a
criminal.
In fact, as I look back on my life,
I’ll tell you this. I got a masters degree
in Criminology. When I was studying
Criminology at Berkeley
I had an impulse. The impulse was to
volunteer to do a work-study program
within the San Quentin Prison, and I did. I was
in the Psychology Track
within Criminology and I volunteered at
San Quentin Prison in the Psychiatric Unit. I
ended up doing
group therapy sessions with murderers
and rapists
there. My intuition was
that I was going to have to spend time
in prison
in this lifetime. I could either do it
voluntarily or I might have to do it
involuntarily, like my friend Darryl Schoon.
After all, this was an era in which
college students in great proportions,
including myself,
were using illegal drugs. I could have
easily gotten busted and sent to prison
like so many people were.
Now, I just bring this up to point out
that we all
have a shadow side, we all have a dark side.
For the most part we prefer not to
look at it.
Beginning to look at yourself deeply
is just the beginning
of exploring the Super Conscious Mind.
Yesterday, and by yesterday I mean the
day before
this monologue is scheduled for release,
which is in about two weeks from today.
The prior day I will have released
the video with Betty Kovács, Dr.
Betty Kovács, called Working on
What has Decayed. There
we begin to address some of the deeper
issues, some of the dark sides associated
with humanity as a whole.
In particular, we look at the Second
World War which
ended just before I was born.
One might say it represented a low point
for humanity
as a whole over the last, let’s say
a million years, in which
humans, Homo sapiens, have been on the
planet. Maybe three hundred thousand, it’s
hard to say.
In any case, a low point. Death camps.
Millions of people murdered.
The Russians alone I think lost
some twenty, thirty million people
in that war. The death camps took,
I don’t know, six million Jews plus several
million others.
Then there were the bombings. I have
been reading about the incredible
suffering
that took place in England with the
bombings of London. Tens of thousands of
people in England were killed
by bombs in that war.
That’s part of our heritage. That is part
of the global heritage of humanity.
We as a species have the capability of
doing that to each other. Not to mention
the mass extinction that is taking place
on the planet right now, sometimes it’s
called the Anthropocene
Extinction. The extinction caused by humans
which has been going on for some ten thousand years, which is
relatively short in geological time.
Humans have done so much. We have
accomplished so very much
in the last ten thousand years. But amongst
those things has been
incredible destruction. Many, many large
species have gone extinct. Many more are
on the verge
of extinction right now because of human
behavior. We could talk about the
pollution of the planet.
There are no
fish that you can get out of the ocean
any longer that don’t have plastic
in their bodies. The waters are
polluted. The planet is overpopulated.
These are simply things we need to
address and digest
because one of the secrets of the Super
Conscious Mind
that I hinted at earlier is that it includes
the most elevated aspects of
consciousness: the consciousness
of Jesus Christ, the consciousness of
Zoroaster, the consciousness of
Buddha, the consciousness
of Isaac Newton
or Albert Einstein
or Shakespeare or Goethe.
The consciousness that created the
Bhagavad Gita.
The consciousness of Lao Tzu
and Confucius and Plato.
All exist within what my friend Marty
Rosenblatt has called The Universe
of Collective Consciousness. It includes
the high and the low. One of the secrets
is that by digesting the stuff
at the bottom you get to experience the
top. One way of expressing that, my old friend
Dean Brown,
of whom I did a monologue much earlier. In fact, I’m going to link
to it because I love that man. If you
haven’t listened to it you might enjoy
it. There will be a link in the upper
right hand corner of
your screen. I know I have to point to
the left because that will be the right
for you when you’re watching.
In any case, Dean Brown put it this way.
He said, “Every lotus flower has its roots
in the mud.”
It’s a Tantric saying. It suggests that
when you want to experience the great heights
and the beauty and the exhilaration and
joy that consciousness offers,
you can get there by opening yourself up
compassionately to the darkness within
yourself. There you’ll understand that you
also share the darkness
within all of humanity.
Before I leave you with those
thoughts let me
suggest that you ask yourself.
What darkness in your life have you been
avoiding?
What little dark space would you
benefit from if you took a good look at it?
If you do that, what do you think might
await you
on the other side if you are willing to
dig into the muck?
Where will the lotus flower point you
next? I’ll leave you with those thoughts.
Thank you for being with me.
[Music]
